title: Fugitive admits to 'honour killing' after 18 years on the run
text:
Soheil Mumtaz (left) was attacked with a hammer by Tabraz Mohammed in the streets in 2001 (Picture: Central News)

A fugitive who beat his sister’s workplace admirer to death has pleaded guilty to murder 18 years later.

Tabraz Mohammed, 39, attacked Soheil Mumtaz with a hammer in the street, near his home in Luton on April 4, 2001.

He found out his victim had been making advances towards his sister at the biscuit factory they worked at together.

Mr Mumtaz, 24, was hit repeatedly over the head and kicked as he lay on the ground before dying five days later.

His attacker fled the country to the US state of New Jersey, where he lived a secret life for almost two decades.

Mumtaz lived a secret life in America before being extradited back to Britain (Picture: Central News)

But he was eventually extradited back to Britain from the United States in August to face trial.

At a hearing at the Old Bailey today, Mohammed, whose last address was given as Southwood State Prison, New Jersey, pleaded guilty to murder.

He was remanded into custody to be sentenced on December 3 at St Albans Crown Court.

As he was led from the dock, there were angry shouts from the public gallery calling the defendant a ‘p***k’ and “son of a b***h”.

description: Tabraz Mohammed has pleaded guilty to murder at St Albans Crown Court over the 'honour killing' of Soheil Mumtaz in Luton, Bedfordshire.
